504 Gateway Timeout Errors

Occasionally, you will see 504 Gateway errors in the admin. This error is usually caused by the server being overwhelmed by some process. E.g., incorrectly set filters. Kinsta controls server resources using a PHP Worker allocation process. Our current account has been allocated 16 PHP workers. Adding more workers is very expensive, so you must figure out what function overwhelms the server. This will almost certainly be a recent change to a plugin.

All product discounts (except for Sale prices) are managed using the Woo Discount Rules plugin. Sample rule titles start with "Example -".

Important Points About Setting Up Product Discount Rules

Always Enable The Discount Bar For Product Discounts

Our product templates are designed to only display discount prices for rules defined in the Woo Discount Rules plugin if you enable the Discount Bar in the rule. The discount will not be shown if you don't enable the discount bar. However, the discount will still be applied when the product is added to the cart!

The Discount Bar Will Always Be Displayed For ALL Product Discount Rules!

Even though you may have the Discount Rules plugin set up to apply the discounts with the Biggest one from match rules, the discount bar will still be displayed for ALL rules! To avoid confusion, you need to define filters so that only a single rule is shown for each product. (Unless you want to show multiple discount bars for some reason.) This also applies if you checkmark the Apply this rule if matched and ignore all other rules option. This will only apply the discount for that rule to the product, but any other rule that is defined for that product will have its discount bar displayed.

Displaying The Customer Name On The Product Page

You can display the name of the customer currently logged into the site on the product page, along with their specific discount price. E.g., Price for Ron Warris : $3.98. To do this, you need to enable the Discount Bar and then include display_customer_name in the Badge Text box where you want the customer's name displayed. This uses the Text Replacement for Discount Pricing snippet to replace the display_customer_name text with the customer's name. Normally you would always define specific User Role filters for any rule that you set up to display the customer name.

Adding, Editing & Managing Product Tabs

The default product page tab setup in WooCommerce includes Description and Additional Information tabs. The Description tab includes the text from the main product description field, and the Additional Information tab includes weight & dimensions data and the product attributes. Tabs and the content in the tabs are managed with the Modify Product Tabs snippet. Here you can rename, hide or add new tabs with the content of each tab defined in the section of code with the function statements.

Docs title: Quadica Order Statuses, Their Meanings and Affects
Docs content:
The Move to Trash function should never be used unless the order status is set to Cancelled. Moving an order to trash while it is set to any other status will NOT de-allocate inventory from the order. Stock will only be increased or decreased by the quantity ordered. E.g., if 10 SP-01W5 were ordered, then the stock would only be decreased or increased by 10 pieces. WC will never allocate more or less stock than what was actually ordered. A spreadsheet with more details about order statuses is here.
Status Name Status is Set By Stock Affect When Set Comments
Site Phone
Awaiting Payment wc-pending Manually set when a new order that is waiting for a wire transfer or check payment is received and reviewed. ▲ Increased ▲ Increased When an order is first received, it will always be set to New, which will allocate stock to the order. If the order payment is Wire Transfer or Check, you would set the status to Awaiting Payment, which automatically de-allocates stock from the order while we are waiting for the payment.
New wc-on-hold This status is always set for new orders received from the website. ▼ Decreased ▼ Decreased Stock will ALWAYS be allocated to an order when this status is set.
Process wc-process Manually set after a new order has been received and reviewed. Automatically set by the OM when all SKUs in a production batch needed for the order come out of production. ▼ Decreased A new phone order can be safely set to Process when it is created.
In Production wc-in-production Automatically set by the OM system when one or more SKUs needed for the order are currently in production.
Ready to Ship wc-processing Automatically set by the OM when a shipping batch is created. ▼ Decreased Stock will always be decreased when this status is set, which will guarantee that no order can be shipped out without stock being properly decreased. Pre-authorized Credit card and PayPal payments are immediately captured when this status is set!
Shipped wc-completed Automatically set by ShipStation when an order has been shipped. ▼ Decreased Stock will always be decreased when this status is set, which will guarantee that no order can be shipped out without stock being properly decreased. Warning! If, for some reason, an order status is changed from Shipped to Awaiting Payment (which would be highly unusual), stock will be de-allocated from the order!
Declined custom Set by the shipper when the credit card capture failed. No Change A declined email message will be automatically sent to the customer.
Hold wc-hold Set by an admin any time that an order needs to be held for some reason. ▼ Decreased A new phone order can be safely set to Hold when it is created.
Pending custom PayPal may set this status if it is verifying a payment. No Change Note that this status cannot be manually selected. It is only used by the PayPal plugin.
Scheduled wc-scheduled Used for scheduled customer shipments No Change A new phone order can be safely set to Scheduled when it is created.
Failed wc-failed Automatically set by Stripe or PayPal if the payment fails or is declined. No Change
Quote
custom
 Used for customer generated quotes No Change
Cancelled wc-cancelled Usually set by an admin. ▲ Increased Note that no payment adjustments or refunds are automatically done by WC. That process is managed manually.
Draft custom Used by the Add/Edit Order process to create draft orders. No Change
Trash Automatically set by WC when the Move to Trash function is used on the order page. No Change Never use the Move to Trash function on the WC order page to delete an order. Doing so will NOT adjust stock levels!
Delayed This status is not currently used.

The following procedure must be followed exactly to ensure that stock levels are adjusted at the right time for the scheduled order. All scheduled orders on a PO are immediately entered into WC when the PO is received.
  1. Go to Add/Edit Orders to create a new scheduled order.
  2. Key in the order details. Be sure that correct product discounts are applied, and the proper shipping method is selected.
  3. Enter the Requested Delivery Date. It could be called "Dock Date" or some variation.
  4. Enter the Scheduled Release Date. This is the date we need to release the order in order to meet the customer's requested delivery date.
  5. Select Net Terms as the payment method. (We cannot accept scheduled shipments for non-term accounts.)
  6. Set the order status to Scheduled.
    Be sure to select Scheduled before you submit the order. Selecting New will immediately allocate inventory to the order.
  7. Repeat this process for all scheduled orders on the PO.

Docs title: Engraving the Bases With LED Shortcodes
Docs content:
1. After Generating the Production Files for Engraving Bases (LINK) navigate to Q:\Shared drives\Quadica\Production 2. Open the corresponding .ODS and .CDR files for the base that needs to be engraved (Ex. RS10 zing.cdr and RS10 Production.ods. The Batch Report will contain the full list of needed frets) 3. Open the .ODS file
  • When the .ODS  is opened for the first time a pop-up will appear, 'This document contains macros..." Select OK.
  • Another pop-up will appear, "This file contains queries. The results of these queries were not saved. Do you want these queries to be repeated?" Select Yes.
  • Navigate to the first tab on the bottom left (Ex. RS10 Engrave). There you will see the Total Panels Required, the Current Panel, and Start Offset
Total Panels Required tells you how many frets are needed
Current Panel tells you which fret you're on
Start Offset allows you to change the location of the codes on the fret
  • After making the necessary changes to the fret it needs to be Exported as a .PDF. Click on the Red PDF Page in the tool bar or go to File > Export as PDF (Do not change any of the settings here, just click Export)
  • When the window to save the .PDF opens the file name should match the name of the fret (Ex. RS10 Production.ODS = RS10 Production.PDF). Click Save.
4. Open the .CDR file
  • Press Ctrl + I or File > Import then select the .PDF file. A pop-up will appear, "Import PDF', do not make any changes and select OK.
  • Take the point of the black arrow and place it where the two grid lines intersect. If there are multiple frets of one type repeat step three and use the Y-Axis to align them.
Each fret type will have differences in fret placement and how far down on the Y-Axis the fret is to be placed. Each .CDR file will contain the information specific to each fret. It is important to read all information provided in the .CDR file before engraving!
5. When all the frets are aligned correctly the files need to be engraved. Press Ctrl + P or File > Print (the default printer should be Epilog Engraver WinX64 Zing)
  • Click on Preferences. A new window called, 'Epilog Engraver Winx64 Zing Properties', should appear. Select Advanced.
  • Click on the Engrave Offset that is needed for that fret. This information is also contained in the .CDR file.
  • Select Load > OK > Apply > Print
6. The file should now appear on the Zing Laser Engraver panel. If the frets have not been placed in the laser now is the time to do so. Ensure the laser is ON (switch on side) and the blower is ON (white button on the laser - Long Press = On & Short Press = Off). Or in the Q-Building app on the phone push the Laser Blower square. 7. Confirm that the name of CDR File Type matches the Board being used in the screen. Press GO (Are the engrave files missing? Reset the location by going to Settings > Bluetooth & Devices > Printers & Scanners > Eplilog Engraver WinX64 Zing > Printer Preferences > Advanced > Q:\Shared drives\Quadica\Production\Laser Offsets\Zing )

Docs content:
You can generate the production (CSV) files that are used to create the PDF files that are imported into Corel Draw for any existing batch at any time using the following procedure.
  1. Go to Order Management > Production > Batch List (LINK) to get a list of generated batches.
  2. Click on the Batch ID that is being worked on.
  3. Click on the Regenerate Production CSV File button.
  4. Save the generated file to Q:\Shared drives\Quadica\Production\production list.csv . Always overwrite the existing file!

After engraving the bases cut out the blank bases so they can be re-used then wipe down with rubbing alcohol, if necessary. Find the needed acrylic inserts and/or solder masks. Get a small glob of solder paste (which sits on the desk) out onto the metal puck. Put the acrylic insert, solder mask, shim and/or matching fret type into the soldering jig. Apply solder paste to the frets/bases. Repeat this process until all frets/bases have been pasted with solder. Take a pasted base and the LED that matches the engraving on that fret (Do Not take out more than one LED bin at a time). Count out the LEDs needed. Place those LEDs onto the fret using tweezers or the vacuum pump tool. Make sure to clean the tweezers/tip of the vacuum pump tool with rubbing alcohol as needed. Place frets that have not gone through reflow soldering onto Grey lined trays!

[Main Oven] Hotplates

  1. Before the hotplates can be used for the first time in the day each plate needs to be power-cycled twice. To do that turn on the hotplate as you would in normal operation but do not put anything on the hotplates.
  2. During the Second Power-Cycle use the Fluke 365 True RMS Clamp Meter to individually test the eight heating elements in the hot plates. To do this place the clamp through the hollow square on the green PCB board housing the heating element wires. If the hotplates are being used in the afternoon this will have to be done a second time.
  3. Make sure the wrist strip is plugged into the grounding outlet before handling any modules!
  4. Remove the completed fret from the Grey Lined tray and place on the Hot Plate.
    • If it is a CoolBase (SR-01, SR-02, SR-03, SR-04, SR-05, SR-06, SR-08, or SR-12) then it does not need clamps.
    • If it is a Aluminium (RS20, RT20, RS10), a SinkPad, Zed, SW, or a Saber2 then it needs to be clamped to reflow solder correctly!
    • If it is a partial piece under a certain size then it also does not need clamps.
  5. Press and hold down the green button for the hotplate that is in use until it beeps.
  6. The cycle will continue with no further input required; The lights beside each hotplate indicate where it currently is in the cycle. When the light turns green and beeps then the cycle is completed.
  7. Make sure the wrist strip is plugged into the grounding outlet before handling any modules! Frets can be removed from the hotplate to a Green Lined tray.
In Case of Emergency! Hit the BIG RED BUTTON if something happens during reflow that is out of the ordinary.

[Back Up] Reflow Oven

Once the LED assembly has been picked and placed it is time for it to go through the reflow soldering process. There is no decisive order for what boards should be cooked first, it is decided on a batch to batch basis. Although, it is usually best to pick and place all the partials in the batch first so that they go through the oven all at once. Below you will find the necessary instructions needed to operate the reflow oven for soldering LED assemblies.
  1. Start the oven by pulling up the emergency stop button and turning the red dial to the ON position.
  2. Turn on the internal fans using the red switch located on the right wall (when facing the oven)
  3. Press Enter when prompted (a short tune will also play to indicate the oven is ready to use).
  4. Use F1 and F2 to scroll through the options menu.
  5. Select PROFILES using the F3 button.
  6. Use the UP and DOWN arrow keys to select a profile.
    • 1-ALM-PAR = Aluminium Star [RS20], Aluminium Tri [RT20], Aluminium Square [RS10] in 50/50, and all partials using the tray. (except SR02). ALL Sinkpads, including partials & Z assemblies.
    • 2-FR 1368 = Coolbase Star [SR01], Coolbase Tri [SR03], Coolbase Bubble Optic [SR06], and Coolbase Quad [SR08]
    • 3-FR4 12 = Coolbase Star/O [SR12]
    • 4-FR4 SQR = Coolbase Square [SR05], Coolbase 4UP [110613], and Coolbase 9UP [08312-3A]
    • 5-FR4 02 = Coolbase 7UP [SR02] using the tray
    • 6-IGNORE
    • 7-FR4 SR4 = Coolbase Side Emitter [SR04]
    • 8-SZ 01! = Full Frets of Z Assemblies.
  7. Once a profile is chosen use F3 to return to the options menu.
  8. Use F1 or F2 to scroll to the WORK option then select it using F3.
  9. Select the F1 button to start the oven.
  10. In the lower left corner the oven will display two words: RAMP and WORK. The oven will flash RAMP as the oven heats to the proper temperature. When it is no longer flashing and displays WORK LED assemblies may be placed onto the conveyor belt.
    • When the oven is first started for the day and after lunch it will require an extra 20 minute warm up after WORK has been displayed.
    • NEVER place a full 100 RS10 fret into the reflow oven, they will not solder properly! Break the board horizontally from the fiducials into two pieces (50 strips per side)!
    • To prevent a pile up there must be a one board spacing between LED assemblies and when exiting they must be moved aside.
    • Never place an LED assembly and a tray in the oven at the same time, and vice versa.
  11. To stop the oven press F3. Press F3 again to return to the options menu. This will also allow you to start from step four to choose a new profile.
    • This step should only be used at the end of the day or if the oven is going to remain idle longer than 20 minutes, such as at break. Once the external fans stop the oven will enter into sleep mode.
  12. Once the external fans have stopped running the oven then can be shut down completely by turning the red dial to the OFF position and pressing in the emergency stop button.
When the LED assemblies have exited the oven and have cooled it is important to inspect them! Time and temperature are key to the reflow soldering process and if the profile is incorrect solder balls can form. This will result in undercooked LED assemblies that will not light and will have to be fixed by either running it through the oven again or using the hotplate. Another problem that can occur, even if the profile is correct, is that not all of the internal fans are running. If this is the case the oven (once clear of all LED assemblies) will have to be completely shut down for ten seconds then turned back on. The internal fans should all start working as soon as a profile is activated.

White Ceramic Hot Plate

  1. Items you will need:
    • Cooling tray
    • Tweezers
    • Metal pick
    • Solder wick
  2. Remove any debris from the ceramic top before turning the hotplate on.
  3. Turn the temperature dial to 300 F°
    • This will take five minutes but do not leave the hotplate unattended.
    • Never fix more than one type of LED assembly at a time!
Determine the cause of the broken LED assembly then follow the instructions on how to fix it:

Tombstone

One of the LED pads doesn't connect with the pads on the base.
  1. Apply a small amount of solder paste in the gap of the disconnected pads.
  2. Using the tweezers place the LED assembly onto the ceramic top.
  3. Wait until the solder liquefies.
  4. Remove the LED assembly from the ceramic top and place on the cooling tray.
  5. Once cooled test with the testing machine.
    • If it lights it can be received then put away.
    • If it does not light follow the instructions for The LED Doesn't Light.

Damaged LED

Such as a shattered lens, a completely missing lens, a chip in the top layer, etc.
  1. Using the tweezers place the module onto the ceramic top.
  2. Wait until the solder paste liquefies then remove the damaged LED from the base.
  3. Place both the LED and the base onto the cooling tray.
  4. Apply a small amount of solder paste to the silver pads where the damaged LED was.
  5. Place the New LED onto those silver pads and put the module onto the ceramic top again.
  6. Wait until the LED assembly liquefies.
  7. Place the module back onto the cooling tray.
  8. Once cooled test with the testing machine.
    • If it lights it can be received then put away.
    • If it does not light follow the instructions for The LED Doesn't Light.
  9. Follow the steps in Complete Rebuild.

The LED Doesn't Light

If the LED fails to light that means it's a short. In these cases it can be hard to determine if the fault is with the board or with the LED so it is best to do a complete rebuild.
  1. Make a note of the LED code and the base type.
  2. Discard the broken LED assembly.
  3. Follow the steps in Complete Rebuild.

Solder Balls Have Formed or Solder Paste is Still Raw

An LED assembly did not reach proper temperature in the reflow soldering oven. It can be reflowed in the oven again or fixed on the hotplate, but not both!
  1. Using the tweezers place the LED assembly onto the ceramic top.
  2. Wait until the solder paste liquefies.
  3. Remove the LED assembly from the ceramic top and place on the cooling tray.
  4. Once cooled test with the red multimeter.
    • If it lights it can then be received then put away.
    • If it does not light follow the instructions for The LED doesn't light.

Thermistor

Sometimes it's not an LED that needs to be fixed but the resistor on the 7UP (SR-02/Sp-02) assemblies. If a custom 7UP (SR-02/Sp-02) assembly needs to be fixed it is best to have LED SKU labels prepared before hand to place the removed LEDs onto.
  1. Using the tweezers place the LED assembly onto the ceramic top.
  2. Wait until the solder paste liquefies.
  3. Correct the position of the thermistor so it lines up with the pads.
  4. Remove the LED assembly from the hotplate and place on the cooling tray.
  5. Test the thermistor to see if it works.
    • If it works it can be put away.
    • If it does not work continue following the steps below.
  6. Place the LED assembly back onto the ceramic top.
  7. Wait until the solder paste liquefies then remove the thermistor.
  8. Put the thermistor and LED assembly onto the cooling tray.
  9. Apply a small amount of solder paste to the thermistor pads on the LED assembly.
  10. Discard the removed thermistor and replace it with a new one from the bin.
  11. Move the LED assembly back onto the ceramic top and wait for the solder paste to liquefy.
  12. Carefully place the thermistor onto the liquefied pads.
  13. Remove the LED assembly from the ceramic top and place onto the cooling tray.
  14. Test the thermistor to see if it works.
    • If it works it can be then put away.
    • If it does not work continue following the steps below.
  15. Follow the steps in Complete Rebuild.

Complete Rebuild

If an LED assembly doesn't light or is damaged sometimes the only fix is to start from scratch.
  1. Refer to your notes on what LED and base type is needed. These items will also have to be subtracted from inventory before proceeding.
  2. Engrave a new base for the assembly that needs to be rebuilt.
  3. Apply solder paste to the base then affix the LED to it.
    • Do not work on more than one LED type at a time!
  4. Place the rebuilt assembly onto the copper hotplate or reflow oven.
  5. Test the LED assembly.
  6. Receive the assembly into the Production Batch if it hasn't already been done.
  7. Place the assembly into it's correct Bin Location by using the Binning Report in the Production Batch or OM Inventory Report.

Putting Lenses Onto A SR-12, SP-12, or SW-12 Board

The equipment needed to glue lenses onto boards can be found on the Testing Bench. All secondary components for the equipment can be found in the three drawers of the Testing Bench. Lenses are located in BB 19 or OS 5 (verify the SKU before using items).
  1. Using the first black button (power button) turn on the equipment. Turn the black knob up until a slight hissing noise is heard. Place the foot pedal onto the floor.
  2. Take out the necessary amount of lenses from the second drawer.
    • The lenses will always be FLP-N4-RE-HRF Optics unless the customer makes a special request.
  3. Remove the orange tip from the glue dispenser and put on a white tipped nozzle.
  4. Press the foot pedal to extrude the needed amount of glue onto the lens.
  5. Place the lens onto the LED Assembly - Be sure to not get glue on the LED lens!
  6. Once the LED Assembly has all the needed lenses move it into The Press for drying.
Note: The Silicone Glue is not tracked in the Order Management System. If the glue is getting low or has expired put that information into the Production Slack Channel.

New Method of Attaching Side Emitter Lenses

  1. Gather the required items listed below before beginning:
    • Latex Gloves
    • F360L-3-RE-0S (also known as F360L-3C-S) optics
      • always verify part numbers before using
    • Micro applicator brush
    • Handheld dispenser with a black tube of UV Glue
    • Wooden Board
  2. Close the blinds before beginning so the outside light doesn't cure the glue.
  3. Put on gloves and squeeze a small amount of the UV Glue onto a wooden board (use less than a dime size amount)
  4. Dip the micro applicator brush into the glue and apply to the silver dots in each of the corners.
  5. Position the optic with the tab over top of the + pad.
  6. Hold the optic down for five to ten seconds, if it still moves continue to hold until it doesn't.
  7. Repeat until the board is complete
  8. Place the board on the UV Turntable until the module has completed one fill spin
Note: All items can be found in the Grey Sliding Drawers of the assembly bench. The lenses can be found in the Grey Cabinet for LED Reels/Overstock/Storage. Note: The UV Glue is not tracked in the Order Management System. If the glue is getting low or has expired put a request for more stock into the Production Slack Channel. Remember to put the Loctite-460 back in the fridge.

Laser Preparation for Cutting Thermal Pads

1. Generate a Thermal Pad PO (LINK/REVISE). 2. Get the thermal pad cutting jig and some sheets of thermal material from beneath the laser. 3. On the laser control panel press 'X/Y Off'. Use the up & down arrows to make clearance room for the jig to fit. DO NOT hit the reset button just yet. 4. Position the cutting jig in the upper left corner of the laser, then place a thermal sheet SHINY SIDE DOWN (THIS IS IMPORTANT) 5. Place magnets in each corner and the middle of each edge on the sheet. 6. Pull the blue bar and the laser carriage over the thermal sheet. Use the manual focus gauge and press the 'UP or DOWN' arrows to adjust the height of the table until the tip lightly touches the thermal sheet. Remove the gauge. 7. Double check to make sure the thermal sheet is SHINY SIDE DOWN. Now the 'X/Y positioning' can be reset by pressing the 'Reset' button on the laser control panel. The lens carriage will home itself in the top corner.

Cutting the Thermal Pads

Note: DO NOT save changes to Corel files during this process! 1. Go to - Q:\Shared drives\Quadica\Luxeon\Thermal Tape\Thermal Stickers Library and open the Corel file corresponding to the next item on the PO. Once the correct file has been opened, delete everything except for the pale blue rectangle. This is used to ensure the laser will cut the sheet to the correct depth. It should not cut through the sheet during the test. The thermal sheet is only cut through when separating pads. 2. In Corel select 'Print' (or Ctrl + P) then go to 'Preferences' > Advanced and select Thermal Stickers, Thermal Stickers Tri, or Thermal Stickers Custom depending on what you are cutting. 3. Click the third tab, 'Colour Mapping', and make sure 'Colour Mapping' is turned on in the upper right corner. 4. Go back into the Advanced tab and hit 'LOAD > OK > APPLY > PRINT' 5. Turn on the blower for the laser. Press 'Go' on the laser control panel. 6. When the test is complete turn off the blower then open the laser table door. DO NOT MOVE OR TOUCH THE JIG. 7. Using a metal pick from the magnetic tool bar carefully remove the test strip from the thermal sheet. If the test strip has been cut through check to make sure the print profile is correct. If the test strip is non-removable check to make sure the manual focus gauge had been set properly. It is also possible that the lens need to be cleaned or that the print profile needs to be checked. 8. If there were no problems with the test strip undo the deletion of the Corel File using Ctrl + Z. Instead, remove the pale blue rectangle from the rest of the file and follow the same print procedure in steps 2 - 6. 9. When the thermal sheet has been cut remove the pieces from the laser and move onto the next sheet if cutting multiples. It is unnecessary to re-do the manual focus unless the laser has been left unattended or was used by someone else. 10. As the laser is cutting the new thermal sheet remove the edges from around the cut thermal pad strips. 11. Once all the thermal sheets have been cut they can be counted and compared to the printed paperwork. If correct follow these steps (LINK) for receiving in completed POs. 12. Exit it out of the Corel file and 'DO NOT SAVE CHANGES!'

Ordering Solder Paste

If more solder paste is needed, go to the Order Management System > Reports > Inventory Reports and search for NC258-M8. Reduce the stock from 1 to 0 so a PO will go through for a new order. Note: It is best to order a new jar when there is 1/3 left in the old jar (175g -weighed in container)) to allow for a two-week lead time if there is no paste in stock.

Receiving Solder Paste

  • Confirm that the paste is 500g AIM NC258-M8 or SAC305-M8 No-Clean solder paste.
  • Confirm that the manufacture date is less than 60 days from the current date or that the best used-by date is at least 120 days in the future.
  • Write the full date that the paste was received on the container. E.g. RECEIVED FEB 1, 2016.
  • Store the paste in the refrigerator. Do not open the container!
  • Receive the solder paste into inventory by going to OM > Purchasing > Receive POs and receiving the PO from Comtree.

Sealed Solder Paste Storage

  • The ideal storage temperature for new, sealed paste is 4°C. Refrigeration will normally double the shelf life of solder paste while protecting the paste from varying levels of heat and humidity.
  • Solder paste cannot be frozen. Temperatures below 0°C will damage the paste.
  • Solder paste should not be refrigerated after the seal has been broken.
  • Any opened solder paste should be stored in the original container at room temperature when not in use.

Preparing Solder Paste For First Use

  • Do not use the paste if the received date is older than 120 days. Discard it and get new paste.
  • Allow the solder paste to reach ambient (room) temperature naturally and completely before opening the jar.
  • Do not force warm the paste. Ideally, the solder paste jar should be exposed to room temperature for 24 hours to reach ambient temperature. While it is best to wait 24 hours, if necessary, this can be as short as 8 hours (overnight).
  • After opening the paste, it should be stirred lightly and thoroughly for one to four minutes. Solder paste should be stirred in one direction with a clean mixing rod only used for stirring solder paste. Stirring the paste ensures an even distribution of any separated material (flux and metal) resulting from storage.
  • Write the date that the paste was first opened on the container. E.g., OPENED FEB 1, 2016

Using Solder Paste

  • If the received date written on the container is older than 180 days, do not use the paste.
  • If the opened date written on the container is older than 90 days, do not use the paste.
  • Do not combine new and used solder paste in the same container.
  • Do not "scrape the bottom of the jar." Once the amount of paste in the jar is less than 125 grams weighed in the container, discard the jar.
  • The solder paste must be at (room) temperature before use.
  • Do not force warm the paste. Ideally, the solder paste jar should be exposed to room temperature for 24 hours to reach ambient temperature. While it is best to wait 24 hours, if necessary, this can be as short as 8 hours (overnight).
  • Before using the paste, stir it lightly and thoroughly for one to four minutes while still in the original jar. Solder paste should be stirred in one direction with a clean mixing rod only used for stirring solder paste. Stirring the paste ensures an even distribution of any separated material (flux and metal) resulting from storage.
  • If the paste is watery, discolored, or otherwise does not look normal, discard it and use new paste.
  • For best results, the temperature and humidity of the areas where the paste is screened onto the board, components added, and reflow soldering is done should be maintained between 20° to 22°C at 45% ± 5% relative humidity.
  • If the temperature and humidity conditions are not maintained at optimal levels, the time the paste can be exposed to air is significantly reduced. For example, at 30°C and 30% - 70% RH, the time the paste can be exposed to the air is reduced to less than three hours. Solder paste is also more prone to defects such as slumping, solder balling, and viscosity changes when applied in excessive temperature/humidity environments.
  • Ensure that the aluminum paste pallet, solder paste masks, and application tools have been thoroughly cleaned using the ultrasonic cleaner at the start of each day.
  • Remove the amount of paste needed for the LEDs you are working on and add it to the paste pallet.
  • Once removed from the jar, the paste must be used within 3 hours. Paste exposed to the air for more than 3 hours must be discarded.
  • Once applied to a board, the components must be added, and the board reflow soldered within 3 hours. If the board is not soldered within 3 hours, remove the components and paste from the board and reapply new paste.
  • When finished, thoroughly clean all tools used for applying the solder paste. The solder paste masks and the aluminum paste pallet must be cleaned using the ultrasonic cleaner.
  • Do not refrigerate any solder paste that has been opened. It must be kept at room temperature.

Unsealed Solder Paste Storage

  • Do not re-add paste that was taken out of the jar back to the jar.
  • Discard any unused paste left on the pallet.
  • Always store the paste in the original jar with the air seal device in place. Be sure to push the air seal device tight against the solder paste to minimize any air contact with the paste. Close the jar tightly and store it at room temperature only.

Emergency Reserved Paste

  • Delays in getting new paste are possible, so we always need to keep one jar of paste in reserve.
  • A reserved jar of paste should always be available at room temperature.
  • Partial jars can be reserved (not less than 375 grams), but they must be maintained within the received and opened dates. Paste after these dates should be discarded and replaced with a new reserved jar.
More details about using and handling AIM solder paste can be found here.

You can generate a new production batch at any time using the following procedure.
  1. Go to Order Management > Production > Create New Batch (LINK)
  2. If there are assemblies that need and can be built, they will be displayed on the page.
  3. If an assembly has a priority (LINK) value assigned to it, those assemblies should be built first as they are required for expedited orders.
  4. Review the page and check mark all the assemblies that you want to include in the batch.
  5. If you have unchecked any assemblies in the Include In Build column, then click the Regenerate button to update the batch.
  6. Once you are satisfied you have all of the items you want to build selected, click the Create Batch button.
    • Note: If an unchecked box is still available at this stage it will be included in the batch so make sure to remove them! (TEST)
    • Note: This step may take some time so Do Not click the button more than once.
  7. The batch will be generated so you can go ahead and create the Production Files and print the Production Batch List. Include an image of a production batch list

Deleting SKUs From a Batch, or Deleting the Entire Batch

If there is an item that has been included in a Batch that should not be there simply click the Delete button in the Delete SKU column that is available at the end of every SKU in the batch. To delete the entire batch you will have to individually click the delete button for each SKU until none remain and then the batch will close out which will return you to the Production Batch List page.

Some Batch Generation Strategies 

  • You can include any number of assemblies in a batch. Even a single one.
  • Orders of large quantities of a singular type should be placed in their own batch.
  • Assemblies that are created with reserved reels should always be in their own batch.
  • Compare the Production List to the Order Status Report. Try to only make a Batch from items that are fully in stock.
  • If there are assemblies that have a priority value assigned to them, create a batch that only includes those assemblies.
  • Only generate batches that you can complete on the same day, or the next morning. Avoid creating big giant batches. Smaller ones are easier to work with.
  • You can have multiple, concurrent batches underway, but it is usually best to only have one batch underway at any one time.

General Terms

OM Production/Shipping Batch Comments

Customer Comments: Text that the customer provided with their order. Internal Comments: Text that we added to the order in the admin. Customer Instructions: Text that has been saved with the customers account. This will always show up with all of their orders. Special Assembly Instructions: Text saved in the Special Assembly Instructions box for a specific product. Will always (and only) show up in a production batch that includes that product.

Production Terms

Shipping Terms

Box Label

This is affixed to the front of the envelope or the side of the box. It contains an Order Number, Customer Name, Company Name, and Shipping Method. It it used to match ALL documents and items being shipped to that package. For example, after affixing Box Label 139367 to the envelope you then would check that the Packing Slip and Certificate of Conformance (if provided) also have Order Number 139367 on them.

Packing Slip

A document that tells us what is needed for an Order. It will include an Order Number, a Shipping Address with the Customer Name, the Shipping Method, and the SKU Part Number with quantity required to ship. There will also sometimes be Order Comments on this document but due to character limitations will be incomplete; view the Order Number in WooCommerce for full Order Comments. After all items for the Order have been picked, verified as correct, and match the Box Label this document will be placed inside the box.

Certificate of Conformance

A document that states that the LED modules we supplied have been built using best practices with genuine components sourced from authorized distributors and are RoHS and REACH compliant. We issue one for ALL LED modules (ex. SP-03-W5), thermal tape (ex. LXT-T-12), and anything else we manufacture/assemble since only the manufacturer can issue a CoC. The thermal presses (ex. LP-01) are not included as they are free of charge. We normally do not provide one for parts we purchase and resell from other manufacturers. This document will include an Order Number, a Shipping/Billing Address with the Customer Name, the Certificate Date, and and the SKU Part Number with quantity required to ship. After all items for the Order have been picked and verified as correct this document will be placed inside the box.

Shipping Label

Commercial Invoice (USMCA/T-MEC/CUSMA)

This document is placed in the front of the pouch so the Order Number is visible for reference. This is important so that it can be used to match the documents to the Shipping Label and Box Label. This document will be included with ALL shipments going to the United States and International locations except for Canada as it shows what items we exporting out of the country.

FDA

This document is for orders going to the United States only.

Certificate of Origin

CERS Export Declaration (replaces B13)

A document provided for Orders over $1,500 USD going outside of Canada and the United States. A message in Slack will appear if this document is needed but always double check the order value for accuracy. Ron will provided this document in Slack and it will need to be printed in triplicate (one sided) and affixed to the outside of the box in it's own document pouch. Be sure to verify that the Order Number, Customer/Company Name, and Shipping Address provided in the document match the Shipping Label and Other Documents of the package it is being affixed to.

To discontinue a product, simply assign it to the Discontinued Products category. You do not need to remove it from other categories. Most changes that need to be made to a discontinued product will happen automatically when you assign the product to the Discontinued Products category, including:
  • If there is no stock available, the product will be removed from all other categories.
  • If there is stock available, a process will monitor stock changes, and when the stock drops to <1, it will remove all other categories at that time.
  • The Meta Name and Description for SEO will be updated to reflect that the product is no longer available. If a substitute product is entered into the Alternate box, then the description will suggest that alternate product.

This details the procedure for creating a new order from a new PO from a customer. Table of typical shipping times by continent and shipping method. When you are done, use the PO Entry Checklist to confirm nothing has been missed.

  2. Click on the Tools option at the top of the page.
  3. Select Scan and OCR > Recognize Text > In This File
  4. Click the Recognize Text button.
  5. Adobe will convert the document to text that you can now cut and paste.
  6. Save the converted document.
Note that some customers will password-protect their documents, and you will not be able to convert them. In that case, you will need to manually key details into the order.

PO is not a PDF Document

  1. Confirm that the PO includes products that are shipped right away. If there are no products to ship within the next 30 days, then go to the Scheduled Orders section.
  2. If none of the products are custom color mixers, then go to WC > Add/Edit Orders.
  3.  If one or more of the products are custom color mixers, e.g., different color LEDs on a multi-LED base, then go to the PO Contains Color Mixer LED Modules section.
  4. Does the PO include an email address that the company wants to be used for all communications related to the PO? If so, enter that email address into the Find or Create Customer box. If not, then use the email from the email message received from the customer.
  5. Is an existing customer found when you enter the email address? If not, be sure there are no spaces before or after the email address. If you still can't find an existing customer, then go to the Creating A New Customer section. When you are done creating the new customer account. continue with step 10.
  6. Once the customer has been selected, confirm and adjust the billing and shipping addresses to match the addresses on the PO.
  7. If the PO Billing address is different, click on the pencil next to Billing Details.
  8. At the top of the box that opens up will be a Select address book entry drop-down box. Click on that to check if there are other addresses that have been previously used that match the address on the PO. If so, select that address.
  9. If there is no matching address in the drop-down list, then enter the correct address details from the PO. When you are done, click the Save as New Entry button. This will save the address so that it will show up in the drop-down address book list for future POs.
  10. If there is a tax ID number included on the PO and if the customer has specified that the order is to be shipped using their own carrier account, click on the Billing Details pencil and enter the Tax ID and own carrier details into the boxes and then click the Done button. (Do not use the Save as New Entry button!)
  11. Once the customer details have been entered, locate the first part number on the PO and enter that into the Find Products box. A list of matching products should be displayed. If none are found, be sure that the part number is ours.

  20. Enter the Customer's PO into Customer PO box.
  21. If the customer has provided a specific ship date, enter that date in the Do Not Ship date box.
    Careful! Do not confuse the ship date with the dock or receive-by date! The ship date is when the customer wants us to ship the order. The dock date is when the customer wants to receive the order.
  22. Enter any special instructions for the order into the Customer provided note box.
  23. Click on the Shipping link to select the customer's preferred shipping method. If they have not provided a shipping method, select UPS Expedited.
  24. Select New in the Order status drop-down box.
  25. Select Net Terms in the Payment method drop-down box.

  27. Click the View Order button and review all of the details of the order. If you need to make corrections, go to Add/Edit Order Details, find the order, and click the Edit Order button.

    2. Select the terms for the customer from the Terms drop-down box
    3. Enter the customer's invoicing email address into the Invoicing Email Address(s) box. If the PO or email message does not specify an email address, then use the email address of the customer who is submitting the order. If the customer specified multiple invoicing email addresses, separate each email address with a comma.
    4. Scroll to the bottom of the page and checkmark the Terms option in the User Roles box.
    5. Click the Update User button
    6. Return to the order.
  29. If all of the details are correct, select the Order Confirmation document from the PDF list and click the eyeball to create the order confirmation to send to the customer.
  30. Change the order status to Process.
  31. Send a PO confirmation email message to the customer. Be sure to confirm that the correct customer email address is selected in the Requester box in Zendesk.

The following guidelines are used to design all of our LED Module MCPCBs. Last Updated: December 7, 2025

Board Design Guidelines

  • The absolute maximum physical array size is 113.8 mm x 148 mm. Anything larger will not fit our equipment. (Updated on Dec 7. 2025)
  • For 500V hi-pot testing, the absolute minimum distance of any live pads or traces from the edge of the board is 0.8mm. If possible, keep live elements at least 1mm from the board edge.
  • The minimum distance between live traces must be 0.8mm. This is important for 500V HIPOT testing.
  • Try to keep at least 0.8mm between live and dead copper. You can go as close as 0.2mm if necessary, but this may cause problems with 500V hi-pot testing.
  • The absolute minimum distance between the board's edge and any copper is 0.35mm.
  • Solder pads should be designed with the solder mask 0.1mm from the edge of the copper.
  • Pads side by side should be spaced at least 0.6mm apart whenever possible.
  • Minimum trace width:
    • For Rebels: 0.2 mm - Max 1A drive current
    • For later LEDs: 0.6 mm - Max 2A current
  • The minimum array size is 70 mm x 70 mm in order to accommodate v-scoring from JLCPCB.
  • Traces should be laid out in 90 and 45-degree angles whenever possible.
  • Traces should connect to pads at 90 degrees if possible.
  • Trace bends should be radiused at 0.5mm. Using radii less than 0.5mm is not recommended.
  • All Rebel boards must have a clear space for printing the 2-digit LED code. This space has an absolute minimum size of 2.2 mm wide x 1.5 mm high.
  • Our preferred font is Tahoma Bold. Use the largest font possible.
  • The font used for the domain part number is TAHOMA Bold.

Design Checklist

Before submitting the Gerber files to the board manufacturer, use the following checklist to be sure nothing has been forgotten.
Drawing Checks
  • Is the array size less than the maximum array size? (See Design Guidelines above)
  • Is the product domain name on all bases?
  • Are all solder pads correctly identified on all bases in the array?
  • Are the traces correctly routed and repeated on all bases in the array?
  • Are the correct holes provided for compatible optics?
  • Have compatible lenses been checked for fit?
  • Have compatible lenses been checked to be sure suitable solder pads are accessible?
  • Have you confirmed that the LEDs are properly centered in all compatible optics? Be especially careful with LED modules compatible with the Carclo Hex holder.
  • Are any of the silkscreen markings covering any of the pads?
Gerber File Checks
  • When you exported the drawing to the Gerber/Drill file, did you select metric as the drawing unit?
  • Have you reviewed every layer using the Gerber viewer to confirm everything is correctly placed?
  • Did you include all of the layers needed for the base?
  • Did you include the drill file in the Gerber export?

Converting Text to Primitives

Any CAD font you use must be converted to line primitives before it can be imported into DipTrace. Many fonts don't display very well in DipTrace, so it's always best to lay out the text in CAD and then convert the fonts you use to primitives. This method also allows you to rotate text at any angle, while DipTrace's text insert function only allows 90-degree angle rotation.
Note that due to the way fonts are handled in CAD, you first need to MIRROR the text vertically. If you don't mirror the text, the following process may not work.
  1. In the drawing, type WMFOUT.
  2. Select a location somewhere to save the file.
  3. Select the text that you need to convert.
  4. Press Enter.
  5. Type WMFIN and select the WMF file that you just saved.
  6. Select an open space somewhere in the drawing to insert the wmf drawing.
  7. Press Enter for the x-scale factor, y-scale factor, and rotation angle
  8. Select the converted text and mirror it back to its original orientation.
  9. Rescale and reposition the converted text over the original text and delete the original font.
  10. Use the solid hatch command to fill the text outlines.

Creating and Importing Extremely Small Text and Other Elements Into DipTrace

If you need to import tiny text, e.g., text as small as 0.15mm high, use the following procedure. This is necessary as DipTrace will not correctly import tiny filled objects. Note that due to the way fonts are handled in CAD, you first need to MIRROR any fonts vertically. If you don't mirror the text, the following process may not work.
  1. In the drawing, type WMFOUT.
  2. Select a location somewhere to save the file.
  3. Select the text and elements that you need to import into DipTrace.
  4. Press Enter.
  5. Type WMFIN and select the wmf file that you just saved.
  6. Select an open space somewhere in the drawing to insert the wmf drawing.
  7. Press Enter for the x-scale factor, y-scale factor, and rotation angle
  8. Select the converted text and mirror it back to its original orientation.
  9. Save just the objects you converted as an AutoCad 2013 DXF file.
  10. Import that DXF file into DipTrace, converting them to Top Pads with Fill closed areas and Embedded Polygons checkmarked. This will correctly import the elements as filled objects.
  11. Export the layer with the objects you just imported (usually the Top layer) as a Gerber file.
  12. Import the Gerber file you just exported and convert the layer with the objects you need to Top Mask.
  13. Now, you can go into the DipTrace drawing and change the object type to whatever you need. E.g., Mask, Silk Screen, etc.

Importing CAD Files Into DipTrace

PCB design is always completed in CAD, with the design imported into DipTrace. To import, use the following process.
  1. Be sure that all spaces that need to be filled are drawn with snapped lines or closed polylines.
  2. All Tahoma font text that is drawn in CAD must be converted to primitive lines using the Express > Text > Explode Text function in CAD.
  3. Use the LISP DXF Prep command to remove all unnecessary elements from the drawing
  4. Save the drawing as an AutoCAD 2018 ASCII DXF file.
  5. In DipTrace, open an existing drawing to use it as a template. Delete the array and save the file in a new directory.
  6. You must close the original CAD file (DXF) before you can import the DXF into DipTrace.
  7. Click File > Import > DXF and select the CAD file.
  8. Change the DXF Units to millimeters
  9. Change the Import Mode to Add
  10. Checkmark Fill Closed areas and Embedded Polygons
  11. Select each layer and choose which layer to convert it to in DipTrace.
  12. Click Import.
  13. Check to be sure everything is imported and filled correctly. If the fill is partial or missing, there are open lines in the CAD drawing.

Generating The Gerber Files

Gerber files are generated in DipTrace using the following procedure.
  1. Click File > Export > Gerber
  2. Be sure that Metric is selected for Units in the Gerber export box.
  3. Click the Export All button.
  4. Select Zip Archive: Gerber + NC Drill 
  5. Select the folder where the DipTrace file is located.
  6. This will save all the necessary files with correct names. For reference, here are the Gerber file names required by JLCPCB:
    • <filename>_TopLayer.GTL
    • <filename>_TopSolderMaskLayer.GTS
    • <filename>_TopSilkLayer.GTO
    • <filename>_BoardOutline.GKO
    • <filename>_V-Scoring
    • <filename>_DirectHeatsink - Thermal Pillar
    • filename>_Drill_NPTH.DRL - Drill Files
This completes the Gerber export process. You must confirm that the files have been correctly generated using the ViewMate Viewer.

Docs title: Why Orders May Not Be Included In a Ship Batch

Docs title: Setting Lead Times for LED Modules in WooCommerce
Docs content:
LED Module lead times are now being automatically determined and updated. The following procedure should not be used.
  1. Go to the WooCommerce Dashboard (open in New Tab) and select Products in the left hand column.
  2. Click on the Add Filter button near the top of the page then select 'Categories'. The second drop down menu should be set to 'Is' and the last drop down set to 'LED Modules'. Click on the Blue Check Mark Box so that the completed filter reads as, 'Categories is LED Modules'. Now select the Filter button to narrow down the results.
  3. Click on the first Check Box that sits in the white bar that displays the column identifiers. The Bulk Edit bar should now appear; under the trash can icon in small text it should say, '...Select All 1,033 items' *this number may change depending on the filters used but it ensures that you're editing all pages and not only the first page of modules*
  4. Under the column identifier for Lead Time click on the Bulk Edit button. A pop-up will appear called Bulk Edit "Lead Time" and it should say 'This will affect all items'. There is a 20 character limit for this box so it is best to keep it short. Some examples are, '1-3 Days','1-2 Weeks', 'Available Mid-October'. Remember to set a reminder to change a Lead Time if it is Date Specific.
  5. Press the Update Button. A prompt will appear that states, 'You are about to update all items. Are you sure? Yes, Update. Cancel.'. Select 'Yes, Update'.

Note: Use the Clear Filters beside the main Filter button to remove all the filters that have been selected at once instead of the X in each individual Filter Box.

Note: Inline Edit should be OFF by Default. Having it ON means specific products will be overwritten by bulk edits.

Note: 'Is Not' can be used in Filters to exclude items to prevent their Lead Time from being Overwritten.

  It is important to become familiar with a variety of filter types as customer quotes are based off website lead times. If a particular base or LED will not be available for some time it would be best to set up the Lead Time differently than those modules that are in stock. Say for example our supplier says that the LED LXML-PR02-A900 will not be available for two weeks but we have 200 LEDs on hand. Using a rough estimate of how many modules we make using this LED it might be best to say 3-5 Days until more stock can be made instead of the regular 1-3 Days for in stock modules. To set up a filter to do this this is one example to do:

Click on the Add Filter button near the top of the page then select 'Module LED'. Change the second drop down menu to 'Is' and the last drop down set to 'LXML-PR02-A900'. Click on the Blue Check Mark Box so that the completed filter reads as, 'Module LED is LXML-PR02-A900'. Then follow Steps 3 to 5 above. Remember to use 3-5 Days in the text box for this example.

Another example would be if bases such as SP-01 won't be available until the Start of March. To set up a filter for that this is one example to do so:

Click on the Add Filter button near the top of the page then select 'Base Type'. Change the second drop down menu to 'Is' and the last drop down set to 'SP-01'. Click on the Blue Check Mark Box so that the completed filter reads as, 'Base Type is SP-01'. Then follow Steps 3 to 5 above. The process of managing overdue invoices and customer accounts is semi-automatic. Note that overdue emails are always sent at 10 AM on business days only. If the notification comes due on a weekend, then the notice will be sent the following Monday at 10 AM.

First Overdue Notice (15 days past due)

The first overdue invoice email (example here) is automatically sent to the customer when an invoice is 15 days past its due date. The following routines generate these reminders:
  • Overdue: N30 Invoice - 1st Customer Email
  • Overdue: N45 Invoice - 1st Customer Email
  • Overdue: N60 Invoice - 1st Customer Email

Second Overdue Notice (30 days past due)

When an order invoice is 30 days past its due date, the Send 2nd Overdue Request Email button will be displayed on the order page in the admin. An email will also be sent to office@quadica.com with details about the overdue invoice and a note saying that it needs to be reviewed to determine if the second overdue notice email message should be sent to the customer. The following routines generates this email:
  • Overdue: N30 Order Payment 30 Days Past Due Admin Email
  • Overdue: N45 Order Payment 30 Days Past Due Admin Email
  • Overdue: N60 Order Payment 30 Days Past Due Admin Email
The second overdue notice email is NOT automatically sent. Instead the order needs to be reviewed and the Send 2nd Overdue Request Email button clicked if it is determined that a second overdue email should be sent to the customer. When the Send 2nd Overdue Request Email button on the order page is clicked, an email (example here) is sent to the following email addresses associated with the order:
  • The email address in the Billing Address section of the order. This is usually the same as the customer's account email address, but it can be changed for each specific order.
  • The email address in the Email box in the Contact Info section of the customer's account page.
  • All of the invoicing email addresses in the Invoicing Email Address(s) box in the customer's account page.
Each email address will receive its own overdue email message. CC is not used. Only a single email will be sent to each unique email address. Duplicates will be ignored.

Final Overdue Notice (60 days past due)

If the order invoice is not paid at 60 days past due, then an email will be sent to office@quadica.com with the order details and the recommendation that the customer account be put on hold. To put a customer account on hold, go to the customer's account in the admin and checkmark the Account On Hold box. This will do the following:
  • You will get a warning message saying that all customer accounts with the same company name will also be put on hold.
  • A text box option will open where the text of the email that is sent to the customer if they try to enter a new order is entered. This text must include the entire email message with details about why their account is on hold. The text entered into this box will typically look like this and include the following details:
    Hello, The Banctec Canada Inc. account is on hold due to non-payment of our invoice 139456 for your PO 4500111324 shipped on Jan 11, 2023. Please reply to this email message to arrange payment of this past-due invoice so we can process your new order. Luxeon Star LEDs luxeonstar.com service@luxeonstar.com
  • Be sure to include the Salutation and Signature lines in the text, and remember to save the changes to the customer account.
  • An automated process will put all of the user accounts with the exact same company name in the Customer billing address on hold. The process will also copy the email message to the user accounts.
Putting the customer's account on hold WILL NOT send out any emails to the customer. This is because, at this point, several emails have already been sent out, and there is little point in sending any more. Instead, if any person from the company tries to submit a new order, then the new order will be automatically put on hold, and an email message (example here) sent to the customer about their account being on hold with a request to contact us to arrange payment so that their new order can be released and processed.

Removing A Company Hold

To remove the account hold for a company, go to any customer account from that company and uncheck the Account On Hold box. This will automatically remove the hold for all other customers from the same company.

The following are statements about SEO made by Google over the years.
  • Backlink Quantity is Irrelevant: A single high-quality link can be more impactful than millions of low-quality ones.
  • Duplicate Content Isn’t Penalized: Google displays one version of the content and ignores the rest.
  • Website Presentation Affects Rankings: Poor visual presentation can negatively influence a site’s perception and search visibility.
  • Ranking Changes Can Take a Month: After quality improvements, it might take up to a month to see changes in search results.
  • Core Web Vitals Are More Than Tiebreakers: They significantly influence rankings and user experience.
  • Core Web Vitals Data Updates Every 28 Days: It takes time for improvements to affect ranking signals.
  • Word Count Isn’t a Ranking Factor: The quality of content matters more than its length.
  • Original Page Titles Are Used for Rankings: Even if Google modifies them in search results, the original titles influence rankings.
  • Heading Tags Send Strong Signals: They help Google understand the topic of a page.
  • Domain Name Keywords Don’t Impact Rankings: Keywords in a domain name are not a ranking signal.
  • Focus Keyword Visibility Is Crucial: It should appear in titles, headings, and throughout the content.
  • Unique Content Should Be Above the Fold: Aim for some unique content in the immediately visible area of a webpage.
  • Spelling and Grammar Matter: Errors can indicate low-quality content.
  • New Content Usually Indexed Within a Week: Time to indexing can vary but is typically around a week.
  • Different Formats Are Not Duplicate Content: Identical content in video and text formats is considered different by Google.
  • Anchor Text Should Provide Context: It helps Google understand the linked content.
  • Long Anchor Text Can Be Beneficial: More extended anchor texts provide more context.
  • 404 Errors Are Normal: They are not treated as negative ranking factors.
  • No Technical Fix for Quality Issues: Improving website quality goes beyond technical solutions.
  • Keep URLs Same During Site Revamps: Changing URLs can lead to a loss in ranking.
  • Multiple H1 Tags Are Acceptable: There’s no limit on using H1 tags on a page.
  • Mobile Versions Indexed by Default: Google primarily indexes mobile versions of web pages.
  • Not All Pages Get Indexed: It’s normal for some pages not to be indexed.

Docs title: How To Use And Update The Quadica Production Layout App
Docs content:
How It Works

When the program starts it polls both the production.csv file as specified in the Control Panel, as well as the Module Base Data sheet. It aquires all production csv data as well as settings data and position data for the codes / base types. The production data is stored and a copy is made. This allows the user to filter the data in various ways and then restore it if they need to. The user selects a base type, which automatically populates a layout pattern with the data. The user is then able to filter or alter the data using the X'ing feature, or by shifting the data with the arrow buttons. The user can also click directly on the codes to modify them as needed. Once they have the data laid out the way they need, they can hit "Save Image" and generate the printable file. The file will be named incrementally based on existing files in the output directory. Files are named seqentially based on the batch and their base type.

General Usage

The app will automatically import data from the production list CSV file that is generated via the OM. You will still need to generate and save this file. The welcome screen will populate with buttons linking to the different layouts depending on what is found in the batch. Each layout will feature a number of frets and will corrispond to an insert to be loaded into the printer for the base type you are working with. The frets host varying numbers of modules, which themselves will have codes laid out onto them. The Base Type dropdown in the bottom left corner can also be used to navigate to different layouts. You can use the Order dropdown to filter the data by order number, having the welcome screen contain only buttons for layouts pertinent to the selected order number. You can also sort by stock, which will similarly only display layouts for which stock products exist in the batch. Layouts themselves will also filter data by order if one is selected. If a given batch contains a total of 200 SP-01 modules, and order number 123456 contains 50 SP-01, filtering by this order number will have the layout for SP-01 display only the 50 modules for this particular order number, where setting it to "All" will have the layout draw all 200 modules. When working with a layout, the center point for each module is indicated by a grey circle. Clicking anywhere inside this circle will toggle the module as X'd. X'd modules will be skipped when the data is being laid out. You can toggle the X's off again by clicking on them. You can also toggle the state of all modules using the "Toggle All X's" checkbox at the bottom, or toggle frets induviduals using the checkboxes at the top. Each code that is laid out on the modules can be changed by clicking directly on the code itself. Doing so will allow the code to be modified, and hitting "Enter" will save the change. You can use "Escape" to cancel the changes and revert the code to it's original value. Clicking Save Image once you have modified the layout to reflect the boards you intend to print will automatically name and save the printable .png image to \Shared drives\Quadica\Production\Layout App Print Files. File names will contain the batch id, base type, and a number which will be automatically incremented. You should delete the images from this directory once you have printed them on the bases. Anything saved to an image will be removed from the list of items remaining to be processed, and once all modules have been procssed the layout will become inaccessible until the program is reset. The Reset button in the bottom right will revert all filtering and modifications. No changes to the product data will be saved.

Control Panel Settings

  • setting | default_value
Settings can be found in the "Control Panel" page on the Module Base Data sheet. Any changes to the sheet may take up to ten minutes to properly take affect Settings:
  • font | arial.ttf
Can be set to any .ttf font type provided it's installed on the machine running the app
  • connector_list | ["XXX","YYY"]
List of all possible connectors that could appear on a base
  • optic_list | ["XXX","YYY"]
List of all possible optics that could appear on a base
  • ir_list | ["XX","YY"]
List of all IR module shortcodes
  • shortcode_colour | magenta
Colour to draw LED codes with
  • connector_colour | orange
Colour to draw connector codes with
  • optic_colour | deepskyblue
Colour to draw optic codes with All possible colour options can be found here

Adding New Board Designs

The app is designed to read critical information from a Google Sheets document found here. Any changes to the sheet may take up to ten minutes to properly take affect. This guide assumes a new insert has been drawn in Corel (G:\Shared drives\Quadica\Employee Files\Russ\Current Projects\Full Fixtures\Cut _ Print ready full fixtures). You will need to get from this file the measurments for the various datapoints that we need to populate the sheet with information about the insert, frets, and modules. To add a new design to the program you must ensure that all requisite data is included in the sheet. Position values are measured in inches. The values in the sheet correspond to position and rotation information for each base type:
  • Base Type
The production code for the fret itself, as it appears in field C2 of the 'production list.csv' (minus shortcodes).
  • Frets
The number of frets to display on the layout.
  • Fret Height
The height of the fret.
  • Fret Width
The width of the fret.
  • Spacing
The distance between the pattern of frets on the insert.
  • First Module X
The X distance from the top left corner of the layout to the center of the first module.
  • First Module Y
The Y distance from the top left corner of the layout to the center of the first module.
  • Module Spacing X
The X distance between two modules on a fret.
  • Module Spacing Y
The Y distance between two modules on a fret.
  • Module Rows
The number of rows of modules on the fret.
  • Module Columns
The number of columns of modules on the fret.
  • LED 1 - LED 7
The led shortcodes to be drawn on the module. Leave blank if unused.
Positions are always given in the format "x_value|y_value". "0|0" represents the center point of the module. The "pipe" character "|" is used to seperate the two values. "0.25|-1.50".
Negative values can be used in positions. To move the text left of center on X (vertical axis) use a negative X value. To move text up from the Y center (horizontal axis) use a negative Y value.
 
← = -X,-Y = ↑ → = +X,-Y = ↑
← = -X,+Y = ↓ → = +X,+Y = ↓
 
  • Module Rotations
Rotation values for each code represented by LED 1 - LED 7.
Rotation values are stored in a single field for an entire module. If a module has more than one LED rotations are seperated with a pipe. "0|90|120"
  • Optic
Location of the optic code (if applicable). Will always share the same format as LED positions. "-0.25|1.10"
  • Connector
Location of the connector code (if applicable).
  • Optic Rotation
Rotation value for optic code (if applicable).
  • Connector Rotation
Rotation value for connector code (if applicable).
Note: Additional functionality exists for the SW-03 and SW-13 to handle the mirroring. Mirrored and non-mirrored values are seperated by a "/" character. "0.50|1.12/-0.25|1.50"

Dependancies and Re-compiling

The program is written in Python and includes the following libraries that may need to be installed via PIP:
  • ghostscript - may require manual install
  • tkinter
  • PIL
  • csv
  • pandas
  • requests
  • io
  • webbrowser
  • os
  • math
The program is compilled using pyinstaller. To do so, open a command prompt, cd to the directory where the "qpla_v0.0.py" file exists, and run "pyinstaller qpla_v0.0.py -F". This will create all the necessary build files and folders automatically in that directory. Currently the program is stored in "Q:\Shared drives\Quadica\Custom Software\Quadica Production Layout App\New Build". Docs title: How To Generate A Credit Note
Docs content:
Credit Notes are issued for returned items or order/invoice adjustments.
  1. Go to Marketing > Coupons > Add Coupon.
  2. Generate a random coupon code. The code must be six digits long and consist of numbers only. It must start with a 9. This is just so that we can identify credit memo coupons.
  3. Add a description of what the credit is for. This information will be included on the credit note sent to the customer.
  4. Select "Fixed cart discount" as the discount type.
  5. Enter the total amount of the coupon.
  6. Leave the Coupon expiry date blank as credit notes do not expire.
  7. In the Usage restriction section, enter the email address of the company or person to whom the credit is issued.
    1. If the credit is for a company, just enter the domain part of the email address with a wildcard. E.g., *@company.com. This will allow anyone from the company to use the credit note.
    2. If the credit note is for a person, enter their full email address. Only that person can use the credit.
  8. In the Usage limits section, enter 1 in the per-coupon and per-user boxes.

Issuing A Credit Note To A customer

Once the credit coupon is created, a Credit Note option will appear in the PDF Invoice box. This option generates the credit note you can send to the customer. The Credit Note document option will show up on all order pages for the customer with the email address entered into the coupon for the credit note. It does not matter which order the credit note is printed from. Only the information entered into the coupon is used to generate the credit note document; none of the order details are used.

Additional Information

Credit notes are not automatically applied to new orders or outstanding invoices. The customer must request that they be used. The Credit Note document includes instructions to the customer about using the credit.

Docs title: Configuring Visual Studio Code To Access Kinsta
Docs content:
Resetting The Hosts Fingerprint

If you get a message from Visual Studio Code that you cannot connect to a domain, the problem is probably an outdated fingerprint file. To fix this:
  1. Go to the C:\Users\ron\.ssh folder.
  2. Open the known_hosts file.
  3. Look for lines with the port number of the site you are trying to access.
  4. Delete all lines with that port number and save the file.
 

Enable Visual Studio Code to Access Files on the Kinsta Server

Generate SSH Keys On The Computer You Want To Use

  1. Open a CMD window
  2. Enter the following to create an SSH key: 
    ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -f ~/.ssh/id_ed25519-kinsta
    You don't need to create a passphrase. Just press enter to create a blank one.
  3. Note the location where the key was saved. Usually C:\Users\NAME\.ssh
  4. Go to that folder, open the id_ed25519-kinsta.pub file, and copy the contents.

Add the Public Key To Kinsta

  1. Go to Kinsta and create a new SSH key. (Usually located in the User Settings section)
  2. Paste the contents from the id_ed25519-kinsta.pub file into the new key and save

Add The SSH Key To Visual Studio Code

  1. Click on the FTP connection icon at the very lower left side of the screen (blue icon)
  2. Click Connect To Host
  3. Click Configure SSH Hosts
  4. Click C:\Users|NAME\.ssh\config
  5. Using the FTP connection data from Kinsta, add a new host. E.g., 
    Host LX-Production
   HostName 34.71.83.227
   User luxeonstarleds
   Port 19039
   IdentityFile C:\Users\ron\.ssh\id_ed25519-kinsta
  6. Always use the same Identity File for each entry.
