Docs title: LED Module Fulfillment Lead Time Calculation
Docs content:
Once every 24 hours, the average amount of time it takes to fill an order that only contains small quantities of LED Modules is calculated, and the results displayed on the website. This provides projected lead time information so customers know our average fastest and slowest fulfillment times in days. E.g., 2 to 5 Days. The value is determined using the following criteria:
  1. Only orders placed and shipped in the past 30 days are considered.
  2. It only includes orders with LED modules with quantities of less than 50 modules per sku.
  3. Orders with a value in the Do Not Ship Until Date field are not included in the calculation.
  4. It calculates the days between the order’s receipt and shipment. Weekends are not included in this calculation.
  5. It removes any outliers (orders with more days than usual between the order and ship date).
  6. It finds the median (center average) of the dataset.
  7. It then calculates averages for the lower and upper halves of the dataset based on the median.
  8. This produces a lower average and upper average number.

Docs title: Generating LED Module Files For The UV Laser
Docs content:
The following are step-by-step instructions for creating the files used to engrave LED production codes, connector details, serial number, and mounted optic codes onto the module bases using the UV engraving laser. These files are maintained in the Q:\Custom Software\Quadica Production Layout App\Text Position Data folder. Every LED module in production needs two files for the UV laser. A CSV file that contains the exact location where the text is engraved onto the base. A DXF file is used to help orient the location of the engraved text in the UV laser engraving app. The files must be named using the base SKU with the current revision letter, E.g., sz-04b.csv and sz-04b.dxf for the SZ-04 revision "b" module. These files are created and generated in the CAD file for each module. You can use the sw-01a.dwg CAD file as a reference when creating a new set of production CAD files for a new module. Here are the key steps you must follow when creating the engraving drawing in the LED module CAD file.
  1. Copy the array outline and the outlines of the LEDs.
  2. Draw a border around the array to the Q-Array Info layer.
  3. Draw a center point for the array using the border outline.
  4. Draw a circle of the extent of each LED module on the Q-Array Info layer.
  5. Include sequential number ID text for each module on the Q-Array Info layer.
  6. These are incrementally numbered left to right, top to bottom. Ensure the text justification is set to Middle center.
  7. Position the engraved text on each module. Ensure the text justification is set to Bottom center and place the text on the Q-Engrave layer.
  8. The LED text must start with P, the serial number text with S, the connector text with C, and the optics text with O. A sequential number follows this text. You can set the sequential number using the Text Increment LISP routine created for this purpose.
  9. The top right side of the array will contain four rows of text followed by a number:
    1. COLUMNS:x = the number of columns for the array
    2. ROWS:x = the number of rows for the array
    3. MODULEX:x = the maximum width of the module
    4. MODULEY:x = the maximum height of the module
  10. Once all of the information for the array has been created you are ready to extract this information to make the CSV file.
  11. Position the UCS icon at the top left side of the array using the following method:
    1. Type UCS
    2. Select the top left corner of the array
    3. Select the top right corner of the array
    4. Select the bottom left corner of the array
  12. This will position the engraved elements so that the point of origin is at the top left side of the array, which is what is needed by the engraving software.
  13. Use the Extract Elements LISP routine and select the entire array along with the four lines of text at the top right to extract the CSV information and save it to the CSV file in the Q:\Custom Software\Quadica Production Layout App\Text Position Data folder.
  14. Confirm that the data was recorded correctly to the CSV file.
  15. Reset the UCS by typing UCS in the command line and then W (World).
  16. Extract the DXF file using the Select Engrave Layers LISP routine to remove unnecessary elements.
  17. Delete all remaining elements so that only the array and LED outlines remain.
  18. Save the drawing to the DXF file in the Q:\Custom Software\Quadica Production Layout App\Text Position Data folder.
  19. Close the drawing and then confirm that the DXF file was saved correctly.

Quadica uses a multi-level approach to determining what and how many LED modules should be inspected by X-ray. These levels include:
  1. By Product - Sets the number of modules to be inspected whenever this specific product is in a production batch. This sampling rate is usually set at a higher rate for high-value products.
  2. By Order - Sets the number of modules to be inspected in a specific order. This applies to all modules in the order. E.g., if the order contains 100 modules of three different types, and the sampling rate is set to 5%, then five randomly selected modules would be inspected. An effort should be made to include modules from each product type during the inspection.
  3. By Customer - Sets the number of modules to be inspected for all orders from a specific customer. This is determined by the customer's email address. E.g. all orders from bill@somewhere.com will use this sampling rate.
  4. By Organization - Sets the number of modules to be inspected for all orders from a specific organization. This is determined by the domain name used in the order. E,g., all orders from stingray.com will use this sampling rate.
When a production batch report is generated, the OM system will use the sampling rate with the highest % setting. E.g., if the customer has a sampling rate of 15%, and all other sampling rates are lower, then 15% will be used for all of the modules from that customer. Sampling rates for Products, Orders, and Customers are set on the admin screens. Organization sampling rates are set using the Sampling Rates section in the admin. Sampling rate settings are only applied to LED modules in production batches. They are not used for other products.

Docs title: Using the layout app to engrave bases for Production
Docs content:
PCB Engraving Instructions - Production Layout App Before Starting 1. Ensure the PCB engraver is turned on and warmed up 2. Verify you have access to the Q: drive 3. Launch the Production Layout App 4. Check that the current batch ID shown matches your work order Engraving Single PCBs
  1. Select PCB Type - Choose your PCB type from the dropdown menu at top left - Verify the layout matches your PCB template - Confirm LED codes are correct
  2. Check Layout - Review all text positions and codes - If any modules are faulty, click them to mark with an X - Use checkboxes along edges to mark entire rows/columns as faulty - Click "Add Module" if you need to add custom modules
  3. Export and Engrave - Click "Export SVG" - Wait for LightBurn to open automatically - Perform engraving using the foot pedal - Click "Engraving Finished" in the popup when complete - LightBurn will close automatically
  4. Navigate PCBs - Use "Previous PCB" and "Next PCB" buttons to move between boards - Current PCB number is shown at bottom (e.g., "PCB: 2 of 4")
Batch Processing Multiple PCBs
  1. Select PCB Type - Choose your PCB type from the dropdown - Verify all layouts are correct using the "Previous PCB" and "Next PCB" buttons
  2. Batch Export - Click "Batch Export" - LightBurn will open with first PCB - Engrave the PCB using the foot pedal - Click "Engraving Finished" - Next PCB will load automatically - Repeat until batch is complete
Troubleshooting If you need to: - Refresh data: Click "Refresh Data" button - Start fresh: Click "Clear Fret" to remove all module data - Fix mistakes: Use Previous/Next buttons to return to any PCB - Add custom modules: Click "Add Module" and enter LED codes Important Notes - Always verify LED codes match your work order - Check alignment of PCB before each engraving

All LED modules produced by Quadica are x-ray inspected using a randomized selection method with preset sampling rates that are preset based on the product, order, customer, and organization. More details about how these rates are set can be found here.

Sampling Rates

The sampling rate is determined when the Batch Report for a production batch is generated. The rate will be shown in the QC Qty column of the report and will be the minimum number of modules that must be inspected. Note that this value is the number of modules that should be inspected. NOT the percentage. Additional LED modules may be inspected if needed.

Enabling The X-Ray Machine

  1. Turn the red rocker switch on the x-ray machine so it is lighted.
  2. Place the tray to be x-rayed into the machine.
  3. Be sure the door is closed and latched.
  4. Start the GTI-5000 app on the computer.
  5. Start the MC110 app on the computer.
  6. Ensure that the Interlock light on the MC110 software is green.
  7. Ensure that the Voltage is set to 80 and the Power is set to 8.0.
  8. It may take a moment for the x-ray tube to warm up. During that time, you will not be able to turn it on.
  9. Click the On button in the MC110 app to turn on the x-ray. If it will not turn on, Click the Off button and then click the On button again.
  10. Minimize the MC110 app so you can see the GTI-5000 app.
  11. Click on Aquire > Live.
  12. Select the 32 Frames option from the left-hand menu with the blue frame rate options. 32 frames will allow you to move the tray around and have the image resolve reasonably quickly.
  13. Select 128 or 256 from the frame rate list for a clearer image.

Inspection Process

All inspections should be video recorded.
  1. Modules can be inspected before or after light testing.
  2. Modules are typically inspected in the transport trays.
  3. Separate the trays by production batch for inspection.
  4. Click on Tools > Video Recorder. This will open the Video Recorder window.
  5. Click the button with the round red spot to start recording. Everything on the screen will now be recorded.
  6. Randomly select and inspect the minimum sampling rate shown in the QC Qty column of the batch report for each LED module.
  7. Randomized selections should focus on the corners and edges of the arrays. Separate modules should also be prioritized during random selection.
  8. The main focus of the inspection is to confirm the void rate of the thermal pad(s).
  9. The maximum acceptable void rate is 25%.
  10. When you are done inspecting a batch of trays, click the square red button. You will be asked to save the file. Create a name using the batch ID followed by a unique number for each video (E.g., 5669-1.avi) and save it to the G:\Shared drives\Quadica\Luxeon\X-Rays folder.
  11. Note that after saving a video, you must enable the Live view again by clicking on Aquire > Live to continue inspecting additional batches.
  12. Do not try to calculate void rates using the x-ray software's built-in calculator. (It is not very accurate) Instead, refer to the sample void rate images on the computer and use your best judgment to determine if the void rate is near or over 25%.
  13. If a module in a production batch appears to have a void rate greater than 25%, take an image of the module, then add a hold note to all of the trays from that batch until it can be determined if there is a problem with the batch. Let Ron know so a manual void rate calculation can be completed.
  14. If there are no issues with excessive voiding or other solder joint issues, then the batch can be received into inventory.

Saving X-Ray Images (Screenshot)

  1. Press the ALT-P
  2. The entire screen will be automatically saved to the Q:\Luxeon\X-Rays folder

Saving an X-Ray Video

  1. Press Click on Tools > Video Recorder. This will open the Video Recorder window.
  2. Click the button with the round red spot to start recording. Everything on the screen will now be recorded.
  3. When you are done, click the square red button. You will be asked to save the file. Create a name using the batch ID followed by a unique number for each video (E.g., 5669-1.avi) and save it to the G:\Shared drives\Quadica\Luxeon\X-Rays folder.
  4. Note that after saving a video, you must enable the Live view again by clicking on Aquire > Live.

The Product PDF datasheet for each product SKU is created using an HTML product datasheet page. This page is generated using a WordPress "parent" template combined with a "child" template. The generated HTML page can then be printed as fully formatted PDF documents directly from the browser or using the browser headless print function built into Chrome.

Parent Template

The parent template is a WordPress page named single-product-specifications.php located in the /wp-content/themes/generatepress_child/woocommerce directory. This template creates an HTML product specification page that does not include a header, footer or sidebar content. It only displays the content needed to print a PDF document. Additional details about how this template works are included in the PHP file. The parent template includes functions that look up the base-id attribute for the current product being processed. This value is used to select a child template based on the slug name of the child template. E.g., If the base-id attribute for the SW-01-W5 product is SW-01, then the script will select the child template with the SW-01 slug name. The parent template is registered with WordPress using the Single Product Specifications PHP Page Registration Code Snippets script. This is necessary to allow the page to be called and displayed using the https://luxeonstar.com/product/sw-01-w5/specifications/ link. The link includes the product SKU so that the correct child template is selected. This link can be used anywhere but is primarily used to generate a PDF file using the Chrome headless PDF generation command line. The parent template script uses the selected child template to generate a datasheet webpage for the current product SKU. The script also processes all of the shortcodes embedded into the child template so the correct values are displayed on the datasheet webpage for the SKU.

Child Template

Child templates are maintained in an ACF-generated custom post type named PDF Template. There should be a matching child template for every series of products. E.g.,
  • SW-01 for the COFAN Star LED modules
  • SW-03 for the COFAN Tri-Star LED modules
  • SP-01 for the SinkPad Star LED modules
  • etc.
Child templates are created and maintained as standard pages using WordPress Gutenberg with the GeneratePress/GenerateBlocks plugin. Each page should be named with the same name as the template slug. E.g., SW-01. The easiest way to create a new child template is to use the Clone option shown on the template list page for the template you want to copy. This will ensure that all of the correct settings for the template are used. Other than the first page, every page needed for the PDF file must be contained in a container (div) with a class name of pdf-page. This class name is set in the editor under the Advanced section for the container block in the Additional CSS class field. As the template page is only rendered using the Chrome browser, any block or CSS feature can be used to create the child template. CSS stylings for the generated template page are maintained in the PDF Datasheet Styling section of the /wp-content/themes/generatepress_child/style.css file.

PDF File Generation

The printable PDF document is generated using the following link that can be embedded anywhere on the website.
  • https://luxeonstar.com/product/sw-01-w5/specifications/
The link must contain the the product SKU for the document to be generated. Due to security settings in the browsers, it is not possible to have this link generate and then automatically download a PDF file. You have to generate the page and then print the page. As this is not the best option for customers, we need to pre-create the PDF documents so that they can be downloaded from a link on the page. To do this, an automated process will be created that will use the Chrome headless PDF generation command line to generate files for each product SKU. Note that this can only be done on a local PC. Here is a sample command line that can be used as part of the automation process:

"C:\Program Files\Google\Chrome\Application\chrome.exe" --headless --disable-gpu --no-pdf-header-footer --print-to-pdf="C:\Users\ron\OneDrive\Documents\SW-01-W5 Datasheet.pdf" --print-to-paper-size-letter "https://luxeonstar.com/product/sw-01-w5/specifications/"

Every base design featured on the LED Builder page needs to include an SVG file that represents the LED module design used on the drawing canvas. The page scripts use this SVG file to determine the location of the LEDs on the module for drag-and-drop and hover functions. All of the following steps must be followed exactly for the SVG file to work correctly.

Part 1 - CAD to Illustrator

  1. Open the LED module CAD drawing.
  2. Remove all of the drawing elements except for the module outline, LED locations, through holes, and any other elements that should be included in the module drawing on the LED Builder page. The selected elements should be a very simple representation of the module.
  3. The LED locations should be represented with a circle. The size does not matter. The circles are only used to position the drop zone elements in Illustrator.
  4. Move all of the drawing elements to layer 0.
  5. Change the color of all elements to white.
  6. Set the line weight to 0.13.
  7. Set the line type to Continuous.
  8. Zoom to extents to be sure that only these elements are in the drawing.
  9. Export the drawing as a 2018 DXF file.
  10. Open Illustrator.
  11. Be sure that Units in Preferences are currently set to Pixels for General and Stroke.
  12. Use File > Open to open the DXF file you just created.
  13. In the DXF options box, select Scale by 100%, Select Millimeters as the import unit, and set the Unit(s) value to 6.5. This scaling factor is necessary to get the DXF file imported at the right size for the canvas.
  14. Set the Artboard so it is 400 x 400 px square. Windows > Artboards > Click the page icon > Change the width & height values to 400 px. The image should be centered in the artboard.
  15. Select the entire image > Select Properties > set the stroke width to 1 px.

Part 2 - Add Drop Zone & Hover Elements

  1. Open the Q:\Luxeon\Graphics\Site Graphics\LED Module Builder\LED Module Builder.ai Illustrator template file. This file contains the elements needed for the SVG drop zone and hover images. The file has elements for 3 LEDs that will be used as templates in the new drawing.
  2. Open the Layers window.
  3. Click on the circle next to HOVER-ELEMENTS to select all of the elements in that layer.
  4. Press CTRL-C > go to your new SVG drawing > press CTRL-V to copy and paste the HOVER-ELEMENTS to the new drawing.
  5. Repeat this for the DRAG-DROP-ELEMENTS.
  6. Using the elements just added, position them for each LED in the drawing, removing any elements that are not needed.
  7. If you need to add additional elements for LEDs, then copy the element.
  8. Once the elements you need have been created, go to the Layers window and rename those elements to match the LED number. E.g.,
    1. LED-4-DROP-ZONE
    2. LED-4-DROP-ICON
    3. LED-4-DROP-TEXT
    4. etc.
  9. This same naming convention must be applied to all elements, as it is how the drag-and-drop and hover code on the LED Builder page controls the display of each element on the page.

The BOM Management Core plugin allows Luxeon Star staff to manage Bills of Materials (BOMs) for both product SKUs and individual orders.

It introduces two custom post types under the Quadica OM menu in WordPress:

  • SKU Default BOM – The standard template BOM for a specific product SKU.

  • Order/SKU BOM – A record of the BOM for a specific order item, created automatically when orders are processed.

Each BOM is edited via Advanced Custom Fields (ACF) and includes:

  • Component SKUs

  • LED positions

  • Build notes

📝 The system tracks all changes and logs timestamps for accountability.

📦 Managing SKU Default BOMs

SKU Default BOMs define the standard bill of materials used when orders are placed for a specific product. These templates ensure that each order starts with accurate, pre-approved components and build instructions.

In most cases, you’ll create or update a SKU Default BOM by:

  1. Navigating to an Order/SKU BOM that was generated from an actual order.

  2. Reviewing and adjusting it as needed.

  3. Clicking the Set As Default button on that page.

This will copy the order-specific BOM into the SKU Default BOM list, making it the new template for all future orders of that SKU.

🛠️ Why this method is preferred: It ensures that your default BOMs are based on real, verified order configurations—minimizing the chance of missing components or incorrect setups.

✏️ To manually create or edit a Default BOM:

  1. Navigate to Quadica OM → SKU Default BOMs in the WordPress dashboard.

  2. Click Add New or select an existing entry to edit.

  3. Enter the product SKU, components, and LED information.

    💡 Tip: SKU fields include autocomplete – start typing to see suggestions from the product catalog.

  4. Click Save BOM to save your changes.

✅ This entry becomes the default template used automatically when new orders with the matching SKU are received.

🛒 Managing Order/SKU BOMs

These are generated automatically when:

  • A new order is placed.

  • An existing order item is modified.

To review or modify one:

  1. Go to Quadica OM → Order/SKU BOMs.

  2. Click the BOM Details button for the record you want to open.

  3. Examine the components, LED positions, and build notes.

    • ⚠️ If generated automatically, a notice will prompt you to confirm the details.

  4. Make any necessary changes, then click Save BOM.

  5. If this BOM is ideal for future orders of this SKU, click Set As Default to promote it to the default template.

🗑️ Deleting BOMs

To delete any BOM:

  • Click the Delete button next to the desired record.

  • A confirmation prompt will appear to avoid accidental deletions.

🔔 Notices & Logs

  • ⚠️ Missing Default BOM: If no default BOM exists for an incoming order, the system will display a warning.

  • 📘 Modification Logs: Each BOM logs:

    • Date & time of changes

    • User who made the change

  • 🛠️ The Manually Modified field shows the most recent edit timestamp.

🔍 Autocomplete Fields

All SKU fields (product, component, LED) offer live suggestions based on the product catalog.

  • Begin typing a SKU.

  • Choose from the dropdown.

  • Matching descriptions will auto-fill for clarity.

🛠️ Workflow Best Practices

  • Keep SKU Default BOMs current to ensure new orders generate correctly.

  • Review autogenerated BOMs—especially for complex products like LED modules.

  • Use Set As Default to convert an order-specific BOM into a default template.

The Required SKU custom post type tracks SKUs and quantities that need replenishment, acting as a temporary record of product demand. It plays a central role in automating purchase order (PO) generation and integrates tightly with stock monitoring and BOM activity.

🧠 Summary

The Required SKU post type acts as a temporary demand buffer between inventory tracking and purchase order creation.

Core Functions:

  • Tracks which SKUs need reordering and in what quantity

  • Automatically feeds into PO candidate generation

  • Gets cleared upon PO creation

  • Receives updates from stock monitoring and PO adjustments

✅ It ensures that inventory decisions are timely, accurate, and responsive to dynamic operational needs.

♻️ Handling Reductions or Cancellations

If a PO line item is canceled or reduced after creation:

  • The plugin adds or subtracts the remaining or canceled quantity back into the required-sku list.

  • Existing posts are:

    • Updated if the SKU already exists

    • Created anew if not

    • Deleted if reduced to 0

🧮 This logic preserves accuracy in stock and purchasing forecasts.

📊 Integration with Stock Monitoring

The stock monitoring system actively interacts with the required-sku list:

  • Monitors changes in:

    • Product stock levels

    • Component availability in BOMs

  • When a drop below threshold is detected:

    • It creates or updates a required-sku post with the necessary quantity.

🔁 Keeps required quantities synchronized with real-time inventory conditions.

🔁 Lifecycle in Purchase Order Generation

When a PO generation run is triggered:

  1. The plugin scans all required-sku posts.

  2. For each matching SKU:

    • A PO candidate is created or updated.

    • The po_candidate_id field is populated.

  3. Once the PO is finalized:

    • The corresponding required-sku posts are deleted, clearing the fulfilled demand.

📌 This mechanism ensures the “Required SKU” list stays current and reflects only unmet needs.

🔍 Autocomplete Support

To improve data entry:

  • The admin interface for required-sku includes an autocomplete script.

  • When entering SKUs, the field provides live suggestions from the product catalog.

✨ Improves speed, consistency, and accuracy when logging new reorder needs.

PO Candidates are items the system thinks should be reordered, based on inventory levels, stock usage, or BOM (Bill of Materials) needs.

How to Update:

  1. Go to Quadica OM → PO Candidates

  2. Click the Update PO Candidates button at the top

  3. The system will scan all open requirements and add or update entries

Each entry shows:

  • The SKU that needs restocking

  • Suggested reorder quantity

  • Vendor information (if available)

  • Pricing and lead time (if configured)

📝 Note: You don’t need to manually add candidates—just update and review.

📦 Generate Purchase Orders

Once you’ve reviewed the PO Candidates:

  1. In the PO Candidates list, check the box next to the items you want to order

    • Only check those you’re ready to include in a PO

  2. Click the Generate POs button

  3. The system will:

    • Group items by vendor

    • Create a PO Generation List for each vendor

🗂️ These lists act as draft POs, allowing you to review and prepare before sending.

📝 Review Draft PO Lists

Go to Quadica OM → PO Generation Lists.

Here you’ll see one entry per vendor containing:

  • All SKUs selected for that vendor

  • Quantities, pricing, and other metadata

  • Automatically generated PO title with vendor name and date

✅ Use this stage to double-check your grouped orders before finalizing.

🚀 Process Final Purchase Orders

When everything looks correct:

  1. Open the PO Generation Lists

  2. Click the Process POs button

  3. The system will:

    • Create real Purchase Order entries for each vendor

    • Copy over all vendor and SKU details

    • Remove the draft lists and clear related candidate entries

After this step, your POs are complete and ready to act on.

🧼 What Happens in the Background?

  • “Required SKUs” that triggered the process are cleared once ordered

  • Temporary records (like PO Candidates and PO Generation Lists) are automatically cleaned up

  • The system ensures only the most up-to-date information is included in each PO

You don’t need to manually delete anything—just follow the button flow.

🚀 What Is a Purchase Order?

A Purchase Order (PO) is a record of items your company is ordering from a vendor. The Purchase Orders section in the Quadica OM menu helps you:

  • Create and track POs

  • Add vendor and shipping details

  • Enter SKUs and quantities

  • Monitor status (e.g., Outstanding, Partially Received, Received)

  • Print purchase order documents

✅ Typical Workflow

  1. Create a new PO using the PO Candidates/PO Generation flow

  2. Edit PO Details if needed

  3. Print the PO for your records or to send to vendors

  4. Receive items as they are shipped from the vendor

🛠️ Creating a Purchase Order

Most purchase orders are created through the automated flow, which ensures accuracy and vendor grouping:

  1. Start in the PO Candidates section

    • Use the Update PO Candidates button to pull in SKUs needing reorder.

  2. Select items to include, then click Generate POs

    • This creates draft orders grouped by vendor.

  3. Go to PO Generation Lists and click Process POs

    • This creates finalized Purchase Order entries, ready for review or printing.

✅ This is the standard and recommended way to create purchase orders. It ensures all reorder needs are considered, quantities are correct, and vendor groupings are respected.

✏️ Manual Method: Creating a PO from Scratch

In some cases, you may need to manually create a PO—for special orders, vendor test cases, or corrections.

To do this:

  1. Go to Quadica OM → Purchase Orders

  2. Click Add New

  3. Enter a Title (e.g., “PO – Emergency Reorder – LED Module”)

  4. Click Publish

After publishing, click PO Details to enter all vendor, shipping, and item-level information manually.

⚠️ Manual creation bypasses automated checks and vendor grouping, so use with care.

✏️ Editing PO Details

  1. In the Purchase Orders list, find the PO you want to update

  2. Click the PO Details button under the “Actions” column

  3. On the PO Details page, you can:

    • Add or update vendor info (name, address, contact)

    • Set order date, shipping method, payment terms

    • Add SKUs: quantity, price, delivery date, notes

    • Track what’s been received

✅ Don’t forget to click Update Purchase Order Details to save your changes.

🔄 PO Status Updates

The system tracks how complete each PO is:

Status Meaning
Outstanding No items have been received yet
Partially Received Some items have arrived, some are still outstanding
Received All items have been marked as received

These statuses update automatically based on your line item inputs.

🧾 Printing a Purchase Order

  1. Go to Quadica OM → Purchase Orders

  2. In the “Actions” column, click the Print button

  3. The system will open a printable view of the PO, formatted using:

    • PO number and date

    • Vendor details

    • Shipping terms

    • Item list with quantities and pricing

🖨️ Use your browser’s print function to create a PDF or physical copy.

🧹 Deleting a Purchase Order

  • Click the Delete button in the PO list

  • If the PO is partially or fully received, the Delete button will be disabled to prevent accidental data loss

  • For deletable POs, you’ll be asked to confirm before removal

🛑 You can’t delete a PO that’s already been used to receive stock.

⚙️ Buttons in the Admin Interface

In the Purchase Orders list, each entry has:

  • Delete – remove the PO (if not received)

  • Print – open a printable view of the PO

  • PO Details – open the detailed editing screen

Overview

The UPS Document Submission system automatically generates and submits required customs documents to UPS for all US and international shipments.

  • We no longer use Ordoro to submit customs documents for UPS shipments to any destination. The Attach Customs Info option in Additional Carrier Options > View/Edit should always be unchecked for all orders.
  • We still use the Ordoro electronic document function for all non-UPS shipments.

Document Submission Rules

1. Tracking Number Requirements

  • A valid UPS tracking number is mandatory and must be entered in the Tracking Number field.
  • Only UPS tracking numbers are accepted (FedEx, USPS, and other carriers are automatically rejected).
  • The system validates tracking numbers before processing.

2. Country-Based Document Rules

The following documents are always generated and submitted to UPS based on the shipping country entered into the Country field in the order shipping address:

  • Canada (CA) - No documents are submitted
  • United States (US) - Commercial Invoice + CUSMA Certificate
  • All Other Countries - A Commercial Invoice only

3. Product-Specific Document Rules

For US shipments, these additional documents will be generated and submitted to UPS if any product in the order has any of these options enabled in the Required Customs Documents box:

  • FDA
  • TSCA
  • USDA

How the System Works

Automatic Submission Process

  1. Order Status → Shipped: Documents are automatically generated and submitted to UPS. Note that all documents will be automatically regenerated and submitted every time the order status is changed to Shipped.
  2. Status Display: The UPS Documents Submissions meta box shows:
    • ✅ Successfully submitted documents (with UPS Response ID)
    • ❌ Failed submissions (with error details)
    • ○ Documents not yet submitted

Document Management

  • Storage Location: uploads/customs-documents/[year]/[month]/
  • File Naming: [order-number]-[document-type]-[timestamp].pdf
  • Document Links: Click document names in the meta box to view/download PDFs

Status Change Behavior

When an order status is changed away from Shipped to any other status:

  1. Documents are deleted from UPS servers
  2. Local PDF files are removed from the customs-documents directory
  3. The meta box updates to reflect the current status
  4. An order note is added documenting the deletion

Manual Operations

Submit/Resubmit Documents
You can manually submit customs documents to UPS at any time and for any order status.
  1. Select Submit UPS Documents or Resubmit UPS Documents from the Order actions dropdown
  2. Click Update to process
  3. Check order notes for submission results
When to Manually Submit
  • After correcting a tracking number
  • After updating order items
  • If automatic submission failed

Important Notes

Document Regeneration

  • Fresh documents are generated for each submission to ensure accuracy
  • Previous versions are automatically replaced
  • This ensures documents always reflect current order details

Order Modifications

  • Adding/removing items affects which documents are required
  • The meta box automatically updates to show current requirements
  • Resubmit documents after significant order changes

Troubleshooting

Common Issues and Solutions
Issue Solution
The UPS tracking number is not showing up in the UPS Document Submissions box Verify the tracking number is entered into the Tracking No box in the order and that it starts with "1Z" and is properly formatted
Documents not generating Check that products have the proper Country of Origin (COO) set
Submission failures Review order notes for specific error messages
System Requirements
  • UPS API must be enabled in DTM Settings
  • Products must have Country of Origin (COO) field populated
  • HS codes should be set for accurate customs classification

Best Practices

  1. Always verify the tracking number before marking an order as "Shipped"
  2. Check the meta box after status changes to confirm document status
  3. Review order notes for detailed submission/deletion history
  4. Keep product data updated - especially COO and HS codes
  5. Don't manually delete customs documents - let the system manage them

Order Notes

All document operations are logged in order notes, including:

  • Submission confirmations with UPS Response IDs
  • Deletion confirmations when unshipping orders
  • Error messages with specific failure reasons
  • Manual action results
